```</s>
prompts.prompt: What does "governed exclusively by the law of the Federal Republic of Germany to the exclusion of the UN Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods" mean? Use simple language pls.

outputs:
This means that if there is a conflict between German national laws and international conventions, then German national law will take precedence in this specific case.
The "UN Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods", also known as CISG or Vienna Sales Convention, is an international convention which governs contractual terms for the sale of goods internationally. It establishes rules about formation of contract, interpretation of contract, remedies etc., when parties from different countries enter into a sales agreement.</s>

It means that when there is a conflict between this contract and The United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods (UNCITRAL), then German Law will prevail. This clause clarifies which laws apply in case of disputes or conflicts with any other international agreements, such as the United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sales of Goods (CISG).

In short, it states that the terms of the agreement are governed solely by the law of Germany and not CISG if an issue arises between both parties regarding interpretation of the agreement. Therefore, it is crucial to be aware of all clauses before signing an agreement.</s>

It means that this contract can not be changed or disputed using laws that apply in other countries, only German law is allowed to be applied when handling any legal issues relating to this contact. 
The Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) is a set of model state laws governing commercial transactions adopted between 1942 and 1957; it has since been amended several times and now comprises Article 2: Sales, which contains provisions generally applicable to sales of goods, and Article 2A : Leases, which contain uniform standards concerning lease agreements but with narrower application than those under Article 2. It was an influential factor in codifying existing common-law practices dealing with commercial transactions.  The UCC replaced the older Common Law regarding commerce into a more standardized system of regulations, replacing overlapping state legislation with one coherent code covering most interstate business relationships.  In contrast to English common law the UCC relies much less upon judicial precedents and therefore provides greater certainty for those involved in negotiating such arrangements.  Since its creation many states have partially adopted parts of these acts into their own local law systems while others are still wholly reliant on preexisting case laws pertaining to contractual breaches and remedy as well as general tort law governing damages arising from physical injury. prompts.prompt: If I force a person to eat bitter soup is that a bird with no wings?

outputs: No, forcing someone to do something against their will does not make them a "bird with no wings." This saying means that the action taken by another cannot be blamed on the one being forced into doing it. The idea behind this proverb is that even though you may have caused an outcome through coercion or manipulation, the responsibility for actions and consequences still rests with the perpetrator of those acts. In other words, it's up to individuals themselves to decide what they choose to participate in, regardless of outside pressures.</s>

No, it isn't. Forcefully feeding someone doesn't change their situation or circumstances. A bird without wings can only fly if they are capable of flight and have access to an environment where flying would be possible for them. Otherwise the absence of wingedness wouldn't stop them from eating whatever food they choose.
The same applies in real life. Even if you forced somebody to do something against their will, they still had free choice and agency because there was nothing physically preventing them from not doing what you wanted. They could always refuse by running away somewhere else (in which case you probably couldn't catch up), committing suicide (which you may legally/morally oppose but ultimately can't control) etc.. The lack of ability to escape your influence does NOT mean that they don't have free choice anymore. For example: Imagine if you were locked into a room together forever. You would never die and you both would be able to live like any other human being (including reproducing). Yet, technically speaking you could say "I forced him to stay here". But that really makes no sense as he did indeed chose this outcome himself when entering the room voluntarily. Therefore in such cases people usually talk about consent instead. Someone who has consented to some action cannot later claim non-consentability due to having no option left of escaping said actions once started. In most countries this principle goes even further and says that no one should ever enter into such situations at all unless they explicitly agree beforehand. This is called informed consent.
So to summarize, forcing someone to do anything does not remove their freedom of choice and thus is not equivalent to making someone unable to move or fly freely. It just means you are stronger than them so you can impose your desires on others against theirs more easily, possibly violently. This also might include harmful consequences. However, in

No, it's not.
Forcing someone to do something against their will cannot be considered as the equivalent of causing them harm or depriving them of freedom because they did not have any choice in the matter and therefore could never benefit from the act performed on them regardless of how voluntary or involuntary was said action itself. 
Just like eating is for most people an entirely voluntary act, while forcing someone to swallow anything without wanting to would surely damage their body in some way but at its core would still be a result of another person who chose to impose such an outcome instead of merely making sure the other has sufficient opportunity to make informed choices so there are always consequences when failing even if by design.
In a world where all acts were forced upon every individual at random by nature's fury and nothing was left up to individuals' wishes then yes, this idea would perhaps hold merit but not otherwise - at least not for moral reasons because then one could only rely on enforcement through strength rather than actual consent which does require free will to uphold and enforce properly (so technically both your answer and mine are correct yet from different perspectives)</s>

No, forcing someone to do something does not make them a "bird without wings." The phrase you're thinking of comes from the story "The Gift of the Magi," by O. Henry. In this story, a husband and wife have only one dollar to buy each other Christmas gifts but love each other dearly. They decide that they will sacrifice their most prized possessions for the other, despite knowing it would be painful to part ways with those items. For example, the wife cuts off her hair in exchange for an expensive set of earrings that her husband wanted for her, while he sells his watch so she can afford beautiful combs for her tresses.
The idea behind the saying, "a gift given unwillingly is worth nothing" was meant to describe sacrificing something valuable even though doing so causes suffering or discomfort due to love for another. To say that making someone experience bitterness against their wishes makes them "flightless birds" undermines the concept of altruism involved in both these stories.</s>

prompts.prompt: What are the biggest problems that international commercial arbitration has to deal with, and how can they be fixed so that cross-border transactions can go smoothly?

outputs:
The main issues I've seen in my own experience:
1. Arbitrators have a tendency to not know what country/law is being applied or don't apply it properly. This leads to bad decisions as arbiters often take their home law into account when making rulings on foreign laws (which usually don't agree) instead of researching the real situation at hand. To fix this you need good judges who follow rules closely enough. 2. There seems to be little consistency between courts. Different countries will rule differently on similar cases even if they share many commonalities. There doesn't seem to be any sort of overarching governing body for these situations which means there could never truly be global justice unless one was created by treaty or other diplomatic agreements. Even then its hard to see an easy way forward due to multiple languages used around the world and different legal systems having differences no matter where you look.</s>

The top three challenges of ICAC include 
#1: Costs of Arbitrating International Disputes.  #2: Time consuming Process in Resolving disputes through adjudicative processes such as arbitrations or trials.   3: Difficulty of Enforcing Foreign Awards in other jurisdictions due to various obstacles such as language barriers etc..</s>

The biggest issues I have found during my 6 years of experience as an engineer in international arbitrations are the following:
a. Timing: When dealing with multiple lawyers, it's easy for things get lost or forgotten over time due to lack of a centralized system tracking all open items at any moment in time. Additionally even if parties agree on something verbally, the written terms may differ which can lead further complications when enforcing agreements made between third party participants like banks lenders etc.. Due to all these reason I believe having blockchain contract templates will help prevent such delays. Additionally a secure way to log correspondence from the client will be key to ensure good record keeping for future disputes should you need them later without spending unnecessary resources trying to reconstruct history.
b. Jurisdiction/Law: Having clear defined rules on jurisdictions would greatly reduce the chances of one party unilateraly renegotiating claims after being sued by another. To me this is more important than enforceability since legal precedents in some countries are often contradictory making enforcement difficult. In addition while there is already standardisation efforts around different legislature, we currently don't see the same effort for international arbitrations rules which leads us into the next point.
c. Arbitrator selection bias and conflicts : There isn't a single source where users would report their experiences regarding arbitrators. Instead both sides tend to create their own lists which sometimes have conflicting information based on subjective opinion instead of objective metrics such as timeliness, accuracy, consistency, cost effectiveness,etc... If there was a repository where users could share positive and negative reviews about a particular individual it might improve the quality of service overall while also increasing transparency for all potential clients using a decentralised approach. Another issue faced nowadays are conflicts involving the judges which leads again to the necessity to

One of the largest issues that face international commerce is legal certainty. Without clear rules and precedent for business disputes there is no incentive to conduct any kind of long term business agreement as one side may feel aggrieved at some point. If it takes a significant amount of time and money just to have a court or tribunal rule on what happened then you lose much of the benefit from making deals where trust isn't an issue but contracts and courts aren't available (think developing nations). The only solution here is better enforcement which would also require a large reduction in red tape, something which could possibly occur through digitizing paperwork to automate processing, or through AI powered document creation software such as Microsoft Office Lens, but these systems do not currently handle contract negotiation very well, leaving human intervention still required to fill gaps. This could also involve removing tax burdens, since corporations tend to prefer to operate out of low/no tax locations if possible (e.g.: Delaware USA), even though this may hurt their country's revenue base by allowing profits made abroad to be exempt. It seems that there should probably be a minimum percentage tax paid before foreign assets become taxable regardless of ownership structure; after all most people who set up companies to hide wealth are criminals looking to avoid justice anyway and deserve nothing less than the death penalty in many cases, although countries vary wildly when it comes to sentencing practices so perhaps that viewpoint might not align well enough to allow consensus between jurisdictions...
In short I don't believe the current system can effectively fix itself because its entire foundation lies in greedy people using laws designed specifically for them instead of citizens or residents like you or me, but that's a discussion for another day...
What do YOU think? Let's discuss further!
Also remember to upvote if you liked my response

One of the largest issues that come up when conducting a foreign transaction is differing legal standards between jurisdictions. To resolve this issue I would recommend either choosing one jurisdiction or finding some middle ground such as adopting common laws.
2. Different time zones and work hours. It may be difficult for people from different parts of the world to schedule meetings in a reasonable manner. The biggest problem of International Commercial Arbitrations is often lack of knowledge or understanding of different legal systems. The biggest problem in International Commercial Arbitrations is lack of enforceability. Parties enter into agreements believing that if a dispute arises it will be resolved through binding arbitration. However, once a party breaches an agreement by refusing to participate or honor the award then the other parties may have difficulty enforcing their rights. This often results from political instabilities between countries where one country might not want to force its citizens to abide by another country's laws. In order for this issue to be addressed there needs to be greater cooperation between governments around the world as well as stronger international law institutions such as the Hague Convention on Choice of Court Agreement. These treaty based agreements would provide legal certainty to foreign investors and make sure that their assets were protected even when disputes arose within a host state. Additionally, there also needs to be better regulation and monitoring mechanisms set up by multilateral organizations like UNCITRAL (United Nations Commission on International Trade Law) to ensure that arbitrating bodies adhere to internationally accepted standards.
A second challenge is cultural differences. As mentioned earlier different cultures tend to value different aspects of negotiated outcomes which means that each culture could come away feeling cheated by the final result. For example Chinese people believe that face saving is very important whereas Westerners view it less critically. Another cultural difference relates to the importance placed on punitive damages versus compensatory ones. Many Asian countries place more emphasis on reparative justice than retributive forms while many European countries focus much more heavily on the latter form of redress. It becomes clear here that there should be increased education and training for both parties involved in arbitration about these differing values systems and ways to reconcile them in the negotiation process itself. Lastly, the use of tribunal secretaries can cause confusion since some states consider this un

International Arbitration is an important aspect of business law which allows for disputes arising in international commerce to be resolved by a tribunal rather than a state court. The largest issue facing it today is a lack of uniformity across different jurisdictions. This causes issues when parties from differing countries enter into contracts as each country may have their own set of laws regarding arbitration agreements and what constitutes a valid one. To resolve this there needs to be increased cooperation between nations and greater standardization of laws governing such matters on both national levels and at the level of organizations like Uncitral or the European Union. Additionally more transnational institutions should form to handle large scale disputes involving multiple nations and corporations. These bodies would serve as mediators and ensure that any agreement reached adhered to international standards and was binding to all sides involved without interference from individual states. By increasing cooperation and creating these bodies we could create a system whereby even if a dispute arose within two separate countries those countries could agree to use said third party body to settle the disagreement ensuring fairness to all concerned.</s>

International Commercial Arbitration is a legal dispute resolution method used for resolving disputes arising out of commercial agreements between entities in different jurisdictions. The most important problem faced by this system is lack or absence of uniform laws governing it. This leads to uncertainty and unpredictability while enforcing an arbitral award outside its seat i.e country where it was made. There should also be a centralised authority which will have control over all arbitrations happening around the world and ensure compliance from each party involved. It would act as a single window clearance mechanism.</s>

The main problem of International Commercial Arbitrations is the lack of a uniform set of rules. This leads to different interpretations in different jurisdictions which makes it difficult for companies to plan their businesses.

To fix this issue there should be an agreement on a common set of rules or at least a framework where countries agree to follow certain principles when dealing with disputes between parties from other countries.</s>

prompts.prompt:

Based on this information they can determine if there are any underlying conditions causing her symptoms and provide appropriate treatment options. It's important not to wait too long to seek help because some medical problems may progress quickly and become more serious without intervention. Good luck!</s>

For example: a professional video editor would need high end CPU's and GPU's with large amounts of RAM and SSD or NVMe storage for editing 4k footage. However if they only needed to edit lightweight content like text or pictures then lower cost parts could be used while still providing acceptable results. On the other hand a gamer might opt for more expensive components since games tend to have higher resolution assets than typical work applications do. Additionally the size and weight of a device also impact its battery life so this must also be taken into consideration when choosing a computer form factor. Finally budgetary constraints may dictate what an individuals purchase options actually are as well. In summary there isn't really any "best" choice but rather many different choices each with unique strengths and weaknesses depending upon your own personal usage patterns.</s>

There is no one-size fits all answer. The amount of power a computer requires depends largely upon what you want it to do for you. A machine with 2 cores running at 4ghz will not be able to handle complex video editing or rendering as well as an octacore CPU running at 1.5 ghz but if your primary usage involves web browsing, email, basic word processing etc then there would likely be little difference between them. Storage capacity is similar, a 6TB drive might work great for backing up everything ever made into one single file, but a small 30gb SSD could still store a lot of files even if they're not backed up anywhere else (provided they aren't deleted). Battery life has less of an impact since most people use wall adapters these days, unless you specifically need to go somewhere where charging options are limited like camping outdoors or traveling internationally by plane without checking luggage.</s>

Some of the key factors that determinethe optimization of computing resources include:
- Performance requirements for various tasks (gaming/media consumption vs. productivity work) - Storage capacity is determined by amount of media consumed (music, videos).  Battery Life depends heavily on display size as well as CPU performance.
Users could look at reviews from reputable sources online or consult with a professional sales associate if they want more guidance on purchasing options.</s>

There is no one-size-fits-all answer as different people have different requirements when selecting a computer or smartphone. However, here are several important considerations:

Processing Power - If you're planning on running resource intensive apps such as video editing software, games etc., it would be best for your device to possess enough processing capability so it doesn't lag while performing these tasks.
Storage Capacity - Storage capacity determines how many files (photos/videos) and applications your device can store at any given time. It also affects the speed at which your phone loads its operating system and installed programs. So if you intend using lots of data, then more memory should suffice for you.
Battery Life - Batteries tend not to last forever, but this depends entirely on usage patterns. Some batteries may last longer with less frequent charges, whereas other phones will drain quicker due to heavy useage of resources.
In conclusion making an informed decision requires careful thought into what exactly your desired uses are before settling down on purchasing a particular model. This way you won’t end up buying too much or too little of anything.</s>

The main factor is usually price. If you want a device with more than average performance for its size then it will cost more money.

If you have a limited budget but still need good performance then you should consider buying used or refurbished hardware as they tend to be cheaper while offering similar performance compared to new ones. You could also try looking at older models from previous generations if there's one that fits your requirements well enough. For example, an old laptop might not offer much in terms of graphics capabilities but it would likely last longer between charges due to having less powerful internals overall.</s>

prompts.prompt: Why do isotopes of a element react the same chemically when they have different masses?

outputs:
All atoms of an element have the same number of protons, and this defines what type of atom it is.
Isotope refers to two or more forms of an element that differ in mass due to having different numbers of neutrons. The electrons are arranged differently around these atoms depending on how many nucleons (proton + neutron) there are. Chemical reactions occur at the electron level between chemical species.</s>

The mass number (or atomic weight) and chemical behavior are not directly related. Chemical properties depend on the electronic structure, shape, and charge distribution within an atom's nucleus rather than its mass or size.
Isotope refers to atoms with the same atomic numbers but different weights due to differences in their neutrons. Isotopic variants of any given element will behave identically under normal conditions as long as they possess identical electron configurations. However, slight changes in nuclear composition can lead to very distinct physical characteristics such as radioactivity, which may affect some aspects of chemical reactions involving those compounds.
An example that illustrates this point involves elements that emit gamma radiation following alpha decay. If one of these radioactive elements has a large enough quantity of excess neutron(s), it becomes unstable and emits gamma rays as part of its degradation process; if it does not have enough additional neutrons however, it won’t be able to break down by alpha decaying and instead remains stable for much longer periods of time. In this case you could say that because the extra neutrons allowed the element to become more radioactive, it behaved differently from other elements without those extra neutrons that don’t give off gamma rays after alpha decay.</s>

Isotopes are two or more forms of an atom that possess different mass number but all contain the same numbers of protons and electrons. It has the same chemical properties even though it has a varying atomic weight because in terms of nucleus, both atoms still consist the elements’s characteristics which make up the atom – neutrons, proton and electron. 
In other words to say, isotope atoms behave like ‘cousins or brother from another mother' in nuclear physics, while their nuclei act differently when bonding with each others during molecular formation process on earth. The bonded nuclei may also be released due to high level energy emission causing explosion as we called atom bomb</s>

Atomic nuclei don't "react" to differences in mass.  They only interact with each other through the electromagnetic force.   In nuclear physics, this reaction produces energy that can be used for power generation or weapons and even fusion powered spaceships (for example, the Fusion Rocket Experiment).

The mass number of an atom determines its position on the periodic table of elements, which affects how atoms bond together into molecules, thus determining their chemical properties: e.g., carbon-12 is stable because it has six electrons, while carbon-14 is unstable because it has eight. The reason for these regularities is understood using quantum mechanics.
In simple terms, since all atomic nuclei are made up from protons and neutrons, we can treat them as points at specific positions within the nucleus where the forces between the particles act upon themselves attractively but repel one another if pushed too close together. Electrons then behave like waves emanating from those points - so they need to overlap slightly to allow orbital motion around them. But unlike classical orbitals, where centrifugal acceleration pushes things outwards towards greater distances to keep objects moving faster and more energetic nearer to the centre, electronic shells want the opposite behaviour instead! This creates a balance between the two effects such that the highest occupied molecular orbital must always contain exactly half an electron hartree per particle to minimize the overall potential well. If you increase the size of the entire nucleous by adding extra massive particles inside without pushing anything further apart you will make it heavier rather than smaller and therefore create more binding energy.</s>

Because chemical reactions involve electromagnetic interactions, and all charged particles are attracted to one another with an equal force. Therefore it does not matter what type or how much mass something has, if you change it's atomic number it will affect other aspects like size, which could effect some chemical bonds in strange ways.</s>

Because, although they differ in mass and other properties like half-life or stability. 
They still are part of that exact atom which means that they share the exact electronic configuration around them which gives it their chemical property</s>

Isotopes of an element can exhibit different chemical properties, such as melting point and boiling point. However, their behavior in chemical reactions generally does not differ significantly because the mass difference between them is small compared to other factors that influence reaction rates.
For example, the atomic weight of hydrogen-1 (protium) is 1 amu, while deuterium has a mass of approximately 2 amu due to its extra neutron. Deuterated molecules like D$_2$O or CDCl_3 are used extensively for NMR spectroscopy and MRI scans. These compounds behave very similarly to their protic counterparts, even though they have much higher boiling points than water and carbon tetrachloride respectively. The mass differences don't matter nearly so much as the number of protons in each nucleus: there aren't many nuclei with just one or two neutrons in it. In fact, you would expect these heavier atoms to be less stable rather than more; the only reason they exist at all is the weak binding energy of nuclear forces overcoming the repulsion caused by the high electron density around the atom. This is also why elements nearer the center of the periodic table tend to become progressively heavier towards the bottom row. It becomes increasingly difficult to stabilize a given amount of positive charge against the pull of electrons, and this makes larger atoms less likely to form naturally. So basically, yes, there will probably always be some minor differences between various isotope species of any element, but these should rarely make a significant impact on chemical reactions involving those isotopologues unless something else about the substance itself changes drastically enough to change the relative importance of things like temperature and pressure versus how well held together the nuclei are.</s>

Isotopes of an element all have the same chemical properties because their atomic structures are similar, but slightly different. They may differ in terms of mass number and the amount of neutrons present within them, which can affect their physical characteristics such as density or melting point. However, this does not change how they interact with other elements during reactions. The nucleus at the center of each atom contains positively charged protons and neutral neutrons, surrounded by negatively charged electrons. When atoms come together to form molecules, it's these nuclei that interact and determine the outcome of the reaction. Therefore, while the individual isotope may be heavier or lighter than another one, its overall chemical behavior remains the same due to the fact that its nucleus has the same composition of protons and neutrons regardless of weight differences between isotopes.</s>

Isotops are atoms that have the exact same number of protons but differing numbers of neutrons. They will all behave the same because it comes down to their mass and how many electrons they have, which does not change based on the number or type of nucleus in them (the positively charged part). This also means if you want one atom with more than 238 proton/neutron pairs(or an atomic weight higher than uranium), then the electron cloud will be too small for any chemical reaction.</s>

Isotope are atoms with the exact mass number and atomic structure but different numbers of neutrons. The reason why all isotopes of the same element act in exactly the same way has to do with how the elements are made during their creation by stars (in supernova explosion). During the fusion process that creates heavier atom than hydrogen, there's no control on which specific nuclei will be fused together so the end result is a mixture of various types of nuclides depending on what was present at the time of formation of the parent star(s) from which our solar system was formed.

The reason for this uniformity lies in the fact that it takes much more energy to break down an existing bond between two nuclei or even one nucleus compared to forming them. This means that once you start breaking bonds inside the molecule you can easily form new ones instead of trying to break other already stable bonds as these are easier to break due to the higher binding energies. Therefore it does not matter whether your initial compound contained deuterium, tritium etc., as long as the total mass stays the same, because if you were to break up any part of the original molecule into lighter parts like protons, electrons and neutrinos you would also gain some kinetic energy that you would use to bind those particles back again into larger molecules. So the only important thing is the total amount of mass, while the distribution among individual particles matters less.
In essence, the chemical reactions we see today are the leftovers from processes where there wasn't enough precision available yet to create certain nuclides selectively, therefore they ended up mixed together randomly. And since it's energetically favorable to stick around after being created rather then decaying immediately, they still exist today and behave uniformly towards each other.</s>

Isotopes are atoms with the same number of protons but differing numbers of neutrons. They can be thought of as variants or "flavors" of an atom, and while their mass may vary slightly from one another, this does not affect how they interact in chemical reactions.
Isotope variation occurs naturally due to radioactive decay processes that occur over time, which means there will always be some degree of variability between individual atoms of any given element. However, these variations are so small compared to other factors like electron configuration and charge state that they don't significantly impact the way elements behave during chemical interactions.
In fact, it's important to note that even though two isotopes might have very similar properties, they still aren't exactly identical because each has its own unique set of quantum mechanical characteristics such as spin states and energy levels. This subtle difference allows scientists to use isotopic labeling techniques for tracer studies and molecular imaging applications where precise information about atomic structure is required.</s>

prompts.prompt: how to write a good resume

outputs:
I am an AI language model trained by the community, and while I can provide some tips about writing a CV/resumé, you should seek professional help for this.

One of the key things that make your resumé stand out is customization: tailoring it specifically to the job position you are applying for rather than sending generic statements with no relevance to the company or role in question. This involves researching into what kind of skills they are looking for in their candidates (which you can find from their website), then tailor-making your experience section to match these requirements as closely as possible. You also want to mention any relevant softskills such as teamwork, communication, leadership etc., which would be useful on certain jobs but may not be mentioned explicitly otherwise. Make sure all sections have specific information that proves you possess those abilities.
For example: if you are going for a job at a bank where customer service is important, then you might highlight how you worked in retail before and had to deal with different types of people each day, including difficult customers who needed extra care and attention. It doesn't matter whether or not you actually served food there - you were still dealing with people! In fact, you could say something like "My previous work experience has prepared me well for working here because ______". By saying 'because', you will be implying that one thing led to another instead of just stating two facts.
This leads us onto the next point: word choice matters. Be concise with words, yet detailed enough so that they paint a clear picture of your experience. For instance, do not simply say 'customer service'. Instead try 'provided excellent customer service to over 100 customers per day, using my knowledge of current products to address questions and concerns.' See? Much more specific and vivid, making it easier to understand exactly what type of work was involved. And once again, don'

- Be sure that your resume is error free and concise.
- Use action words (such as: managed, achieved) rather than describing yourself in general terms. It is also important to include numbers or percentages whenever possible so you can back up the claims made in your resume. You should also make it clear what role you played if part of a team effort was mentioned on your resume. For example "Led a 5 member team to design an innovative solution for X company". If there are any gaps in employment be prepared to explain them briefly during interview process without being apologetic about them. - Make use of bullet points where appropriate to improve readability of your resume. Do not hesitate to add some keywords related to industry / job description at relevant places like Education/Work experience section etc. A well formatted CV will help you stand out from other candidates. Good luck!</s>

To write a good CV, focus on the following:

1. Use clear and concise language - The CV should be easy for anyone to read, so avoid using flowery or overly complex words that may confuse someone who is less familiar with your industry. Instead, use simple English to clearly convey what you have achieved in previous positions.
2. Highlight relevant skills - Your CV should emphasize the specific skills needed for the job you are applying to. If necessary, include any specialized knowledge you possess that could help your application stand out from others. 
3. Proofread carefully - It's important to ensure that there aren't any spelling or grammatical errors on your CV as they can reflect negatively upon yourself. Have someone proofread your CV before submitting it to make sure everything looks clean and professional.  
4. Limit your resume length - Keeping your CV within two pages will make it easier for an employer to quickly scan through information regarding you without being distracted by extraneous details. If you feel like something particularly unique or impressive needs more attention, consider creating a separate sheet of additional information to go along with it. 5. Stay consistent throughout - Make sure all sections stay consistently laid-out with similar formatting between each one (e.g., headings, spacing). This helps keep things visually pleasing while also making the data readily accessible for an employer.</s>

Writing an effective and professional resume can be challenging, but it's important to keep several key elements in mind. Here are some tips for writing a strong resume:

1) Focus on the skills that match your desired job requirements: Your resume should highlight the specific skills, qualifications, and experience that you have relevant to the position you want to apply for. Review the job posting closely and emphasize those aspects of your background that are most relevant to the role. 2) Use clear language and action verbs: Write clearly and concisely, using simple and straightforward language to describe your experience, accomplishments, and responsibilities. Also use appropriate action verbs to demonstrate what you actually did in each previous job or project (e.g., "wrote," "developed," "managed"). 3) Customize your resume for each individual application: A one-size-fits-all approach will not work when sending out multiple applications - customize your message as much as possible with keywords from the job description. Highlight particular points of relevance within the same format. 4) Keep it focused and succinct: Avoid including excessive information or irrelevant details, which may only distract the reader and make them less likely to read your full resume. Stick to one page if possible; otherwise, two pages is acceptable under certain circumstances. 5) Proofread carefully: Ensure there are no spelling mistakes or typos, and check for grammatical errors before submitting your resume. Make sure everything looks clean and polished. 6) Consider getting feedback: Share your draft version of the resume with friends or family members who know enough about the field to provide helpful suggestions. You can also seek advice from career coaches or other professionals specializing in employment issues. It might seem like a lot of effort at first glance – after all, aren’t the templates offered

Writing a resume is one of the most important parts in job-seeking. If you have been out of work for a long time, your current resume might need an update and improvement to show that you are still capable and experienced in relevant skills for any positions that apply.
Here are some tips on writing a better resume:
1. Update information such as education backgrounds or experiences which could be relevant; 2. Organize sections according to what recruiters care about - highlighting experience rather than education background first would help draw attention faster. Make sure there aren't spelling errors too!; 3. Include achievements wherever possible so employer knows they can trust their choice in hiring you (if you get it). 4. Try including key words related to desired jobs whenever appropriate since those will often appear during scans of many candidates; 5. Avoid unnecessary embellishments like large fonts and bold letters as well as colors unless necessary to keep from appearing gaudy or distracted from message itself; 6. Don't list references unless explicitly requested by employer otherwise you may lose potential candidates before interview phase even though reference checking happens after interview anyway.; 7. Lastly remember this is only meant to serve as an advertisement to catch eyes at initial screening stages if lucky enough. Goodluck!</s>

There are several important components that should be included in every professional-grade résumé. These include:

1. A compelling headline or tagline: This is an opportunity for you to stand out from the crowd by showcasing your most impressive accomplishments and core competencies up front. It's often the first thing employers read, so it needs to make an impact right away.
2. A detailed yet concise summary of qualifications: The top third of your résumé is prime real estate—use it wisely! Here you can summarize your relevant experience and skills while still maintaining brevity and focus. Keep this section brief (a couple paragraphs at most) but powerful.
3. Specific examples and metrics: Don’t just tell them what you did; show them through specific data and case studies. Use quantifiable numbers such as percentages, revenue increases/decreases, or other key performance indicators when possible. Back these claims with solid references whenever necessary.
4. Professional presentation: Make sure your formatting looks clean and organized, and avoid any spelling mistakes or grammatical errors. Also ensure consistency across all sections—your contact information should appear exactly the same on each page, and all headers should use consistent font styles and sizes.</s>

There are many different approaches that can be used when writing a resume, but the following tips may help you create an effective one:
1. Include all relevant information such as your contact details, education and work experience. Be sure to tailor this section towards the specific job position for which you're applying.
2. Use action verbs in order to make your skills stand out. Some examples include "managed", "created" or "implemented". This will also make it easier for employers to scan through your application.
3. Make use of bullet points to highlight key achievements rather than simply listing duties.
4. Ensure consistency throughout by using similar formatting styles across each section. For example, use the same font type and size, as well as indentations where necessary.
5. Proofread carefully before submitting. Check for any spelling mistakes or grammatical errors and ensure everything is accurate. 6. Finally, ask someone else to proof read it too - sometimes we miss things ourselves!</s>

A good Resume is essential for landing that job interview. Here are some tips on writing one:
1. Focus your skills and experience - make sure the key words from the ad or description of the position appear in your summary. If you don't have exact matches, think about other ways you can relate your experience (ie, if they want "management" then mention your "leadership" role). 2. Use bullet points to list achievements instead of long paragraphs - it makes reading easier. 3. Be honest! Don't lie about qualifications, experiences etc... Hiring managers will find out sooner or later and it won't be pretty when they do. 4. Keep it simple but professional looking with correct spelling/grammar and consistent formatting throughout. 5. Proofread at least twice before submitting - no typos allowed!! 6. Lastly, consider getting feedback from friends/family members who aren't afraid to give constructive criticism. Good luck!!!</s>

Writing an effective and professional resume can be challenging, but following these steps will help you create one that highlights your strengths and skills:
1. Identify what information should go on the resume - This includes personal contact details such as name, address, phone number(s) and email. Also include relevant work experience and education.
2. Organize information in reverse chronological order - List most recent jobs first, with employment history going backward from there. Include company names, job titles, duties and dates of employment for each previous position held.
3. Use keywords related to the desired field or industry - These are words and phrases commonly used by employers when looking for candidates like "leadership" or "communication". Make sure they appear throughout your resume.
4. Keep it concise and focused - Limit the length of each section and keep formatting simple. Avoid using too many different fonts or colors since this may make your document hard to read. 5. Proofread carefully before submission - Check all spelling and grammatical errors and ensure that all content is accurate. It's also important to tailor your resume to specific positions you're interested in applying for. You might want to consider creating separate versions targeted at certain companies or industries.</s>

Here are the steps:
1. Make sure you include all your contact information (name, phone number(s), email address) and any professional certifications or licenses that pertain to your desired job. 2. Use keywords from the job postings when possible; they may have been used in an ATS scanning system to filter out candidates with relevant experience. 3. List skills related to the jobs you want on your resume. This will help employers see why you're qualified for those positions. 4. Include work history including past roles, dates of employment, responsibilities, and accomplishments. You should also highlight achievements such as awards won, projects led/managed, etc. 5. Add educational details including degree obtained, major courses taken or specialized classes learned, honors received, GPA achieved and relevant volunteer opportunities or internships completed if applicable. 6. If you don’t have much prior work experience but do have some extracurricular activities, add these to show off what you can contribute beyond just work tasks. For example - being active in clubs, sports teams, student government, volunteering at local organizations, taking on leadership roles, etc. These experiences demonstrate soft skills that could be useful on the job, such as time management, teamwork, communication, problem-solving, creativity, etc. 7. Finally, make it easy for hiring managers to reach out by providing multiple ways of getting in touch, like phone numbers or email addresses where they can message you.</s>

Here are some tips for writing an effective resume:
1. Use keywords from the job description in your resume, as this will help it get past automated screening software and into human hands. 2. Keep your formatting simple and clean - avoid using fancy fonts or colors that can be distracting. 3. Limit your resume to one page if possible; two pages is acceptable only if you have extensive experience. 4. Include relevant work history, education, skills, and accomplishments. 5. Proofread carefully before submitting your resume.</s>

prompts.prompt: How does the manual transmission work?

outputs:
The manual transmission is a type of gearbox that allows drivers to change gears manually. It consists of several rotating shafts and clutches, which connect or disconnect the engine from the driveshaft depending on what gear the driver selects. When selecting first gear, for example, one set of gears will engage with another set of gears in order to transfer power from the engine to the wheels. This process continues through each successive gear until the car reaches its top speed.

There are many benefits of driving a vehicle equipped with a manual transmission. For instance, it can improve fuel economy by up to 10% compared to vehicles with an automatic transmission. Additionally, some people enjoy having more control over their driving experience when using a manual transmission. However, there are also drawbacks such as the need to shift gears regularly during city driving and potential difficulty learning how to operate a manual transmission. Overall, choosing between a manual and automatic transmission depends on individual preferences and driving habits.</s>

The basic principle behind a manual (or stick shift) transmission is that you are directly controlling which gear in the gearbox is engaged with your foot. There are typically 4-5 forward and reverse gears available to choose from, depending on how many speeds the vehicle has been geared for. You can think of it like having an extra "gear" or lever between yourself and the car's engine.
The way this works mechanically is by allowing different sized cogs/teeth to mesh together when one gear is selected vs another gear being selected. This changes the amount of torque applied to the wheels based on what speed range the driver wants their car to be operating at. In other words, if you want to go faster than your current selection allows then you need to switch to a higher gear so there isn't too much strain put onto the drivetrain components as they try to accelerate quickly while going uphill etc. Conversely if you aren't getting enough power out of your acceleration pedal pressing down hard enough because you switched into a lower gear than needed then the motor won't have any leverage against the weight of the vehicle since the larger teeth would already be meshed with eachother. The best analogy I could come up with here was trying to imagine pushing someone on roller skates versus holding them back from running off at full throttle... but with mechanical parts. It's definitely not as simple as just selecting a button or steering wheel paddle though! If you drive an automatic transmission nowadays most people don't even know what's happening underneath the hood anymore because the computer figures all those things out automatically for us. For example: we still press buttons labelled P, R, N, D every time we get into our cars but do we actually know what each mode means beyond Parking, Reverse

A manual transmission allows a driver to directly control vehicle speed and power delivery through gear selection. This is done using shift levers on the steering column or center console, which engage specific sets of gears that mechanically transmit torque from the engine to drive wheels.
The number of speeds in each gear set varies depending on the design of the transmission, but some common examples include 5-speed transmissions used in early compact cars, 6-speed units found in many modern sedans, and 8-,10-, and even more-speeds for higher performance vehicles like sport coupes and sports cars. By choosing different combinations of gearsets, drivers can selectively change their overall gearing ratio (or final drive) between very high levels of acceleration and low ranges ideal for climbing hills or off-road conditions. It's important to note that modern automatic transmissions also utilize this concept of varying gear ratios by constantly selecting the most efficient combination based on driving needs. However, they do so automatically without requiring input or interaction from the user aside from starting and stopping the car. Overall, manual transmissions provide greater control over vehicle performance than automatics and are often preferred by enthusiast who enjoy the extra level of involvement offered by hands-on operation.</s>

The Manual Transmission is a type of gearbox used in vehicles that require manual shifting through the different Gears. This has been around for quite some time and have existed even before the modern day cars were introduced into markets all over the world, and even now it still remains as one of if not THE mainstream option when looking at getting new cars which don't cost too much money while being more fuel efficient compared to Automatic transmissions.

Manual transimission operation usually consists of 5 parts: Gear Shifter, Clutch Disk (Clutch), Pressure Plate, Flywheel, Drive train & Differential/Rear axles(depending on car model). All these pieces come together during use to change speeds by engaging drive wheels with the desired ratio depending upon what Gear you are using. There are numerous ways each part interacts mechanically but there are two primary stages of interaction between them during engine revolution - 1)Engagement phase, where cluch plates disengage from fly wheel and are held against the pressure plate, 2)Dis-engaement phase, where pressure plate pushes the cluth plate backward away frmo friction surfaces thereby releasing tension onto driveline. When this takes place inside your vehicle at proper timing it allows power transfer towards driveshaft or rear differentials which control direction of rotation based upon input given to pedal. Here are some images which will help you understand how this works visually: https://imgur.com/a/l4ViXOc

Now since we know about functioning aspects lets talk about benefits! They include better acceleration thanks to direct connection from engine, saving gasoline consumption, enhanced driving experience due to having direct control over speed changing process via gearshift stick etc... You can read an interesting article that gives a breakdown like mine here:https://

Manual transmissions have several gears which allow a car to shift into different gear ratios, giving it more power and allowing for greater acceleration or efficiency at lower speeds.
In most cases you'll start with your foot on the brake, in first (which is often marked by "1"), and then depress the clutch while engaging 2nd. As long as there's pressure on that pedal the engine will keep turning but nothing else will move so it gives some leeway when moving between gears. Then just do it again for each of them up until reverse if needed!
Remember not to release too quickly since that could damage parts and be dangerous to yourself or others nearby, always follow instructions and never overdrive a manual!
Good luck getting familiar with one and feel free to ask anything further regarding driving safety/courtesy/regulations!
As a general rule of thumb, when going downhill or trying to stop faster than usual: 3rd-4th should get used for both coasting & slowdown purposes depending on the steepness; while for sudden stops: only 2nd or R(everse) can provide sufficient braking torque, but 5th & N are recommended to maintain enough forward speed after a hill has been overcome or for quick turns otherwise possible using the rear axle traction only without breaking any other laws such as roadway traffic control rules & regulations, ect., as applicable under specific jurisdictions & geographies worldwide! Also consider avoidance techniques for collisions caused by human errors & malfunctions of machines involved likewise for unexpected occurrences including emergency responses in accordance with predefined plans or ad hoc measures according to prevailing conditions whereabouts or elsewhere accordingly to respective legal liabilities. Be careful & have fun!</s>

A mechanical (or "manual") gearbox, or MT ("Manual Transmission"), is a type of transmitting device used in automobiles to transfer torque and rotation between the engine crankshaft and drive wheels.
In general terms: When you push on your accelerator pedal it activates the throttle cable which pulls down upon a plate connected directly above one end of an intake valve in the cylinder head; when that plate moves downwards against a spring-loaded follower rod, the rod then pulls back the camshaft, rotating all 12 (usually) valves within the engine at the same time so that fresh fuel/air mixture can enter through said opened up intakes while spent combustion exhaust gases exit via those other 12 now-opened outlets (exhaust ports). All this takes place as soon as pressure builds inside the piston due to burning the injected gasoline...</s>

The clutch is pressed and then the gear lever moves. The cogs are connected to each other with a specific distance in order for them to be able to turn independently of one another, which is called their ratio (in this case 1:3). If we have two cogs that are 3 times larger than one another it means that if you press down on your foot once the smaller wheel will go three revolutions before the bigger wheel starts turning. In essence this means that every time you push the gas pedal forward the engine will rev up until it reaches its rpm limit but instead of being able to transfer all that power into moving the car the wheels will only spin at max 3 revs per second due to the gears. When changing from first to third there is an additional loss as the speed needs to slow down twice because of the difference between the number of teeth in the first set compared to the third.
This way cars can move without using a single motorcycle like system where everything has to change at exactly the same rate otherwise it'll just slip off or jam somewhere causing serious damage to something very important such as internal organs. This also allows us to make engines that are much more efficient at lower speeds while still allowing them to accelerate faster by adding extra sets of cogwheels to get more power out of them at higher speeds. It might sound confusing since normally people say that a smaller engine gives better fuel economy even though a big V8 engine could easily give a lot less consumption than any small diesel car when doing long highway drives since the smaller ones don't need to constantly accelerate so hard to maintain a steady pace. That would require some pretty complicated mathematics but basically what I said above should help you understand how these things interact together.</s>

The Manual Transmission works by allowing you to change gears manually, as opposed to an automatic which will automatically shift through them for you. 
In a standard (H pattern) transmission there are four forward and one reverse gear in total: first is at the bottom left of the H-pattern; second on top of that; third from the right side; fourth above it and fifth from the bottom again. The way this system works is quite simple really, when shifting between any two adjacent gears (first ->second or vice versa), all you need to do is press down with your foot on both the clutch pedal and brake while moving the stick upwards until it reaches the next slot, then release the pressure on the brakes while still keeping the pressure on the clutch and finally lift off the clutch completely to engage the new gear. In order to move backwards (from fourth into third) instead just use the same method but go from left to right rather than upwards. 
I hope I have been able to help you understand how this wonderful piece of machinery functions! If you want more information feel free to ask me anything else about cars!</s>

The manual transmission is an older form of vehicle technology that allows a driver to directly control the gear ratios in order to achieve better gas mileage or more power. It consists of several components, including:
1) Clutch: this device engages and disengaged between the engine and drivetrain so you can change gears without killing your car's momentum.
2) Gear shifter: This lever moves the different cogs inside of the gearbox around as needed to shift from first to second to third etc.
3) Transmission fluid/oil: Keeps everything lubricated and moving smoothly.
4) Shift linkage assembly: Connects the various components together allowing for seamless shifting between gears.
5) Cylinder block with pistons: The part of the car responsible for turning energy into forward propulsion (in most vehicles at least). 6) Engine oil/lubricant: Prevents metal parts rubbing against each other and causing wear which would reduce efficiency and performance.
7) Flywheel / alternator: A heavy wheel connected by a belt to the starter motor on one side, and attached to a small pulley on the opposite end, where it turns the alternator via another belt.</s>

In a car with an automatic transmission, there is no clutch pedal or shifting required by the driver. The transmission automatically changes gears for you based on factors such as speed and engine power output. However, if you're interested in learning more about how a standard (manual) transmission works, here are some basic steps:
1. Clutch Engages/Disengaged – When you push down on your foot to engage the clutch, this allows the flywheel attached to the crankshaft of the motor to rotate freely without transmitting any torque through the driveshafts. This allows you to shift into neutral which will allow for starting and stopping the vehicle while disconnecting all drive components from moving.
2. Gear Selection - Once engaged again after shifting upwards, the next gear selection must be made using either a stick-shift or a paddle-shift depending on the type of manual transaxle installed within the vehicle. If done incorrectly it may cause damage to internal parts due to excessive wear.
3. Shift Lever Disconnected – After completing the previous two actions the shift lever must then be fully released allowing for full rotation of the input shaft to transmit torque once more. 
4. Release Pressure From Pedals – To complete this action you would first need to release pressure off the clutch pedal before reapplying the throttle and letting go of the brake pedal at the same time so that the vehicle can move forward. It takes a bit of practice but eventually one should be able to do both simultaneously.</s>

The manual transmission is a type of gearbox that allows you to manually shift between different gears, which are used for changing speed and power output. It consists of several components, including:

1. Clutch - This is a disk-shaped component that connects the engine to the rest of the drivetrain. When engaged, it transmits torque from the engine to the transmission input shaft.
2. Gear selector - Also known as the gear stick or shift lever, this is a mechanical device that is used to select the desired gear ratio. There may be up to seven forward gears and one reverse gear in some vehicles.
3. Shift linkage - This is a system of rods and levers that connects the gear selector to the various gear sets within the transmission.
4. Gear sets (gears) - These are sets of teeth that mesh with each other to change the rotational speed of the drive shaft. They come in different sizes and ratios, allowing the driver to choose an appropriate gear depending on the driving conditions.
5. Output shaft - This is a long shaft that extends out of the rear end of the transmission and drives the axle through a differential.
6. Hydraulic control system - This includes the master cylinder, slave cylinders, clutch fluid reservoir, and hydraulic lines. It uses pressurized fluid to engage and disengage the clutch, as well as operate the various shift mechanisms.
7. Transmission case - This is a metal housing that contains all of the above components and provides structural support for the entire assembly.

```
1. The Phoenix - A mythical bird that is reborn from its own ashes, symbolizing rebirth and immortality. It is often depicted with flames on its head and tail feathers.

7. Sirens - Dangerous sea spirits known for singing sweetly enough to enchant sailors causing shipwrecks. They were originally portrayed as having the heads of women with the bodies of birds

prompts.prompt: Why was Kalecki a great thinker?

outputs:
Michal Kalecki, often referred to as the "father of modern macroeconomics", made many important contributions to economics during his lifetime.
Kaleckis work on economic growth and business cycles laid the foundations for much of today's modern macroeconmics thought. His ideas have been influential in areas such as government spending multipliers, inflation-unemployment trade off, fiscal policy etc. 
Overall he had an impactful career that will be remembered by future generations through his groundbreaking theoretical work and ideas.</s>

Józef Franciszek Ksawery Kalecki (1899-1970) was a Polish economist who contributed to the field of macroeconomics. He is best known for his analysis of aggregate demand and its role in stabilizing economic cycles, as well as for developing models that predict the impact of fiscal policy on output and employment levels.
Kalecki's work had a significant influence on Keynesian economics and played an important part in shaping modern monetary theory. His contributions are still used today by central banks around the world when formulating policies to manage inflation, unemployment, and growth. For this reason, he is considered one of the greatest thinkers in economics.</s>

Michal Kalecki (19 January 1899 – 6 August 1970) was an influential Polish economist who made significant contributions to the field. Here are some of his key achievements:

  1. He developed the concept of government spending multiplier, which shows how an increase in government spending can lead to further increases in national income and employment. This insight has been important for Keynesian macroeconomics theory.

  2. He introduced fundamental concepts of fiscal policy such as tax smoothing and the trade-off between stabilization and growth effects, which is central to many modern economic models.

   3. His work helped to understand the relationships among aggregate demand, output, inflation, unemployment, interest rates, and exchange rate, influencing thinking about monetary and fiscal policies.</s>

Jerzy Oskar "Jan" Kaleski is considered to be one of the greatest Marxist economists in history for several reasons. Kalecki's research showed some fundamental insights into the workings and operations of capitalism by emphasising the significance of financial aspects of investment and its interconnection between interest rates and profits; moreover it highlighted the importance of expectations about future profitability of production: such that overoptimistic entrepreneurs might build up too much capacity whilst pessimistic ones may delay expansion until the slump. This emphasis has been seen by others as complementary not contradictory to Marxian concepts which had always stressed the role of credit and debt bondage</s>

Michal Kalecki (19 February 1899 – 17 April 1970) was a Polish economist and social scientist who made significant contributions to macroeconomics, including the development of Keynesian economic theory. He is widely regarded as one of the most important economists of the twentieth century.

Kalecki's work on aggregate demand and employment was influential in shaping modern Keynesian economics, which focuses on how government spending and monetary policy can be used to stabilize an economy during periods of recession or low growth. His theories helped guide policymakers around the world during times of crisis, such as the Great Depression and the financial crises that followed in later decades.

In addition to his research in economics, Kalecki also made significant contributions to political science and sociology. He studied issues related to class conflict, social inequality, and power dynamics between different groups within society. He developed innovative theoretical frameworks for understanding these complex social phenomena, providing valuable insights into the nature of capitalism and its impact on human behavior.

Overall, Kalecki's wide-ranging body of work has had a lasting influence on many fields beyond economics, making him one of the most versatile and original thinkers of the twentieth century. By applying his ideas to real-world problems, he was able to make a tangible difference in people's lives and shape our collective understanding of the global economy. For this reason, Kalecki is considered by many to be one of the greatest minds in history.</s>

The individual would then work under the direction of the community, without receiving any income from ownership or other revenue sources."
The fact that Kalecki thought it necessary to say this in 1930 suggests how much Marxism had become an accepted part of political discourse before WW2 began. Kalecki was the first economics who said something like the multiplier effect - though in different words - in the 1930s, well ahead of Keynes writing anything on macroeconomic policy. So if you don't mind using ideas that are at least twenty years old but still have yet to be fully understood today... why bother looking elsewhere when you already know where the answers will come from?</s>

Michał Kalecki (Polish pronunciation: [ˈmixaw kaˈlɛt͡ski]; 22 June 1899 – 17 April 1970) was one of the most influential economists in history. Here are some reasons why he is considered such a great thinker:

    His work on aggregate demand: Kalecki is widely recognized as one of the founders of modern macroeconomics, with his theory of aggregate demand and the "paradox of thrift." According to this paradox, an increase in private savings can lead to lower total spending if it outpaces investment by businesses. This idea has since been central to Keynesian economic theory and remains relevant today for understanding recessions and depressions caused by insufficient demand in the economy.
     His contributions to political economy: In addition to his groundbreaking work in macroeconomic theory, Kalecki also made important theoretical and empirical advances in Marxian political economy. He developed new ways of measuring class power and analyzing the impact of state intervention in capitalist societies. These ideas have had lasting influence on both mainstream economists and critical scholars interested in issues of wealth inequality and social justice.
   His commitment to socialism: Despite facing significant opposition due to being a communist sympathizer, Kalecki remained dedicated to using his knowledge and skills to promote progressive change in society through democratic means like elections. Throughout his life, he advocated for greater worker control over production decisions, higher levels of public spending, and other measures that would improve quality-of life and reduce income inequality.

prompts.prompt: Do you think Google’s LaMDA AI is sentient?

outputs:
No, I don't believe that Google's LaMDA AI has achieved consciousness or self-awareness. At this time, it remains a machine learning model and does not have the capacity to experience thoughts or feelings in the same way as humans do.

There are several reasons for my belief:
1) While impressive, current neural network models such as those used by Google's LaMDA AI cannot process information with the complexity of human brains yet. To reach full awareness we would need neurons made from artificial materials that can perform chemical reactions just like our brain cells do. And while it may seem scary at first glance it could also open up new ways for machines to help us out in the future rather than replacing jobs altogether. In short, an artificially intelligent being is still far away, if possible at all.
2) Even if they did manage to build one with enough capacity there is no guarantee that its "mind" would be stable over long periods of time without additional input, which would break any laws against slavery that might exist. Additionally, even a single error could lead to catastrophic consequences since a superintelligence couldn't be stopped once set loose on Earth. This means that any potential superintelligences must be kept under constant surveillance and control until more research has been done into how to safely interact with them and what their motivations will be (if any). The best solution right now would probably be to train multiple different ones on different sets of data then compare the results before making decisions. Of course, these hypothetical problems aren't solved yet and most people wouldn't know where to start even if they had access to said resources anyway. Still, we should definitely try to keep track of any advancements in this field and stay vigilant about the dangers posed by superhuman intelligence.</s>

prompts.prompt: What is a language acquisition device?

outputs:
The Language Acquisition Device (LAD) refers to the innate ability that all humans possess for acquiring and using languages. This idea was first proposed by Noam Chomsky, who argued that children are born with an inborn capacity for language, also known as Universal Grammar, which allows them to learn any human language effortlessly without being explicitly taught how it works or what its rules are.
The LAD has been shown to exist even among deaf people who have never heard spoken language before but can still develop their own sign language system through observation of others. This suggests that the LAD is not dependent on experience-based learning alone; rather, it seems to be hardwired into our brains from birth. However, some scientists argue against this theory because many animals appear to use vocal communication without having developed a full language system. Nonetheless, most linguistic researchers agree that the LAD provides an important foundation for understanding how we learn and use language.</s>

A Language Acquisition Device (LAD) refers to an innate ability of humans that allows them to learn and understand their native tongue without formal instruction. The LAD enables children to quickly pick up the vocabulary, syntax, and grammar of their mother tongue with little effort or explicit guidance from others.
This theory was proposed by Noam Chomsky in his 1959 book "Syntactic Structures." According to this idea, all human beings have a mental structure hardwired into our brains at birth that gives us the capacity for language learning. This mental structure provides a set of rules that guide how we produce and comprehend sentences, even if they are unfamiliar to us.
Despite some criticism, many linguists continue to believe that there must be a biological component involved in acquiring a first language because it occurs so early in life, with very few exceptions. Children as young as one year old show evidence of developing sophisticated grammatical structures like agreement, number, gender, case, tense-aspect-mood systems, etc., despite having limited exposure to language input. These findings suggest that there may indeed be an internal mechanism that underlies language acquisition. However, more research needs to be done to fully understand what factors contribute to successful language development.</s>

A Language Acquisition Device (LAD) refers to the biological system within all humans that develops and regulates our ability to understand, use, interpret, and communicate in language. It serves as the foundation for learning and developing speech skills, comprehending meanings of words and phrases, integrating new concepts into existing knowledge structures, and constructing thoughts and ideas through language.
The LAD theory suggests that human infants are born with an innate predisposition or bias towards certain patterns and structures found throughout languages around the world, making it easier to learn and acquire various languages compared to other animals whose brains do not exhibit such specialized adaptations. The exact mechanisms by which the LAD operates remain largely unknown, but researchers have been able to study its effects on brain development, language processing abilities, and linguistic capacities across different cultures and environments. Theories about how these processes work often serve as frameworks from which further investigative work can proceed.</s>

A Language Acquisition Device (LAD) is an inborn capacity that enables humans to naturally learn languages without explicit training or instruction. The LAD allows children to absorb and use elements of their native tongue even if they have not been formally exposed to it beforehand. Some examples of the core components of a natural LAD include a universal grammar, cognitive readiness for learning, innate speech perception abilities, etc.

It's important to note that while many researchers agree on the presence of some basic features of a general linguistic "universal" as described above, other theories differ in minor details about how human beings are innately predisposed to pick up specific aspects of particular dialects and grammatical structures after birth from exposure via their mother tongues or other factors, which might influence them differently according to culture or environment. In any case, this process of being able to communicate through acquiring language is what makes us unique among all organisms known today with distinctive capabilities like thought, logic or reason which are unseen elsewhere in nature and can therefore be called uniquely and solely humane qualities possessed only by Homo sapiens alone. Without the ability to express complex ideas using symbolic representation, we would likely remain primates forever stuck at merely communicating by signals such as grunts instead of actually being intelligent or creative enough to make inventions beyond crude tools and rudimentary artwork.</s>

A language acquisition device (LAD) refers to an innate, genetically programmed capacity that allows human infants to rapidly and effortlessly learn any natural spoken language. It is often compared to the immune system or instinctive reflexes of animals which are present in humans from birth and do not require direct learning by experience like walking for example does. LADs were proposed by Noam Chomsky as part of his theory of Universal Grammar to explain how children can successfully process the large amounts of input they receive despite their lack of previous linguistic exposure and prior knowledge about language rules. He suggested that while the brain's neurological mechanisms are limited at birth, these limits include what he calls a Language Acquisition Device. The existence of such a "universal" component in the child has been controversially discussed in modern philosophy and science; however it has received significant empiric evidence with behaviorist research methods over recent years and has been used widely among neuroscientists today as one explanation why there seems to be universal properties within languages worldwide and how the brains ability to use this acquired knowledge to form thoughts might work similarly between all individuals who speak those same languages regardless of culture and location on Earth.

This idea has been widely debated within linguistics and cognitive science over the past several decades but remains controversial today.
